Long Update: You can turn on a Hierarchical Modeling setting for Interactive Modeling

Short Update: Intergerated Modeling Enhacement: Model Repository
Long Update: The model repository enables you to reuse custom models for multiple time series and for multiple pipelines in a project

Short Update: Hierarchical Modeling Enhacement
Long Update: The Hierarchical Modeling node has been updated. You can now specify the reconciliation level and disaggregation method for this node. You can also set the default pipeline template to be used for each level in the hierarchy

Short Update: Interactive Modeling Enhancements
Long Update: Changes have been made to the way the Model Selection List table lists the models. The champion model for each selected time series is always at the top of the list. When you select a different time series
Document Link: the champion model appears at the top and is always selected. If you sort the models in the list
Example Link: the champion model is sorted as you specified. To return the champion to the top of the list

Short Update: Interactive Modeling Enhancements
Long Update: You can select multiple models for a time series and delete them with a single click"

Short Update: Enhancement to Action: mtsTrain

Short Update: Enhancement to Interactive Modeling: fit ESM

column8: and IDM models to any time series in the project. These models have been selected by default and could not be changed. You can now deselect any of these models if you do not want them evaluated for each time series

Long Update: The THRESHOLD= option is now optional; by default

Short Update: Enhancement to how the Filters pane shows the default attributes
Long Update: The Filters pane shows the default attributes (BY variables) in the Time Series Viewer

Short Update: Enhancement to the Auto-forecasting node: Specify an external model
Long Update: You can now specify an external model to be included for the Auto-forecasting modeling node. You can specify the model to be used by providing the caslib and table name where the model is stored

Short Update: In Interactive Modeling

Example Link: the usage of independent variables and events in system-generated ARIMA models are automatically set to Force to use if their inclusion does not cause the model to fail

Short Update: Enhancement to Proc: MTS

Short Update: New Proc: MTSSCORE
Long Update: This new procedure implements scoring and diagnostics for the Mahalanobis-Taguchi system
Document Link: which is a statistical method for fault detection and diagnostics of multivariate data

Short Update: New Proc: MTS
Long Update: This new procedure implements training for the Mahalanobis-Taguchi system
Document Link: which is a statistical method for fault detection and diagnostics of multivariate data

Short Update: Interactive Modeling Node Enhancements
Long Update: The OUTWEIGHT (Weights of Constituent Nodes) table is generated for the Interactive Modeling node. This table indicates the champion model for each series. This is helpful when the Interactive Modeling node has more than one predecessor node. You can view this table using the Save Data node or
Document Link: if Interactive Modeling is the champion node in the pipeline
Example Link: you can view it by opening the results of the Model Comparison node.

Short Update: Interactive Modeling Node Enhancements
Long Update: For any time series that you select in the right pane
Document Link: you can set all of the forecasts to zero or missing. This change must be committed before you exit the Interactive Modeling node. This change affects only forecasts in the horizon. It does not affect forecasts in the out-of-sample region.

Short Update: New Action Set: MTS
Long Update: The new MTS action set includes the mtsDiagnose

Short Update: Enhancement to Data Management: When the source data for a project is updated

Short Update: Enhancement to ATSM Package: The DIAGNOSE object has been enhanced
Long Update: with the new IDMTEST.LENGTH option
Document Link: The new IDMTEST.LENGTH option enables you to specify the method to be used to determine the time span of the dependent series that is supplied as input to the intermittency test

Short Update: Enhancement to ATSM Package: The DIAGNOSE object has been enhanced
Long Update: with the new HORIZON option
Document Link: The new HORIZON option enables you to specify the time span of the dependent series that is used to diagnose the best intermittent demand model (IDM)

Short Update: TSM Package: VERBOSE option
Long Update: The 'VERBOSE' option of the TSM object is now documented. This option has been available since the LTS 2022.1 release. You can use it to enable the generation of additional log messages

Short Update: TSA Package: TSA.MOVINGSUMMARY() method has changed
Long Update: The behavior of the TSA.MOVINGSUMMARY() method has changed. Messages for any issues that are detected during parsing are written to the log. Messages for any issues that are detected when the method runs are written to the OUTLOG table. To access the run-time messages
Document Link: you must specify appropriate options to create the OUTLOG table and to capture messages of desired types in that table

Short Update: New Proc: TSGLOBALRECON
Long Update: This new procedure enables you to adjust base forecasts across all levels of a hierarchy to obtain a new set of reconciled (or coherent) forecasts
Document Link: such that the reconciled forecasts of the lower levels of data disaggregation add up to the reconciled forecasts of the upper levels of aggregation

Short Update: Enhancement for SAS Model Studio: The parameter estimates table (OUTEST) can now be selected as an output table for Interactive Modeling
Long Update: The parameter estimates table (OUTEST) can now be selected as an output table for Interactive Modeling. When an Interactive Modeling node is added to the pipeline
Document Link: the parameter estimates table is selected by default

Short Update: ATSM Package: EVENT object
Long Update: EVENT object: Detailed information has been added to explain and illustrate the usage of SAS predefined events. This includes several tables that define event keywords and explain the naming of predefined events

Short Update: ATSM Package: DIAGSPEC object
Long Update: DIAGSPEC object: The default for the 'TRANSFORM' option of the SetIDM() method has changed from 'AUTO' to 'NONE'. This change can result in generation of different intermittent demand models (IDMs) than in previous releases. To restore the previous behavior

Short Update: New Proc: TSSELECTLAG Procedure
Long Update: The new TSSELECTLAG procedure computes the lag at which the cross-correlation between two series is maximal. It enables you to estimate the delay between two time series. It offers a choice between two kinds of correlation
Document Link: the Pearson correlation and the distance correlation

Short Update: Custom templates & nodes in The Exchange

Short Update: New Proc: TSCUSTINT procedure loads user-defined discrete time interval definitions
Long Update: The new TSCUSTINT procedure loads user-defined discrete time interval definitions into the SAS system. This procedure is used in conjunction with the INTERVALDS= system option to implement a custom time interval. You can use custom time intervals in functions and procedures that support the use of SAS predefined time intervals such as DAY and HOUR

Short Update: Enhancement to the ATSM Package: Clarification on the SetUCM method
Long Update: SetUCM method of the DIAGSPEC object clarifies how different component options work and how the DIAGNOSE object diagnoses a UCM model when no UCM component options are specified

Short Update: Enhancement to the ATSM Package: Clarification on the SetIDM method
Long Update: SetIDM method of the DIAGSPEC object clarifies the differences between PROC HPFDIAGNOSE and DIAGSPEC objects in how the IDM family is handled

Short Update: Enhancement to the ATSM Package: Clarification on objects
Long Update: Replay method of the FORENG object clarifies how the specification of the INEST object works. Further

Short Update: Enhancement to the ATSM Package: Clarification on multiple methods
Long Update: Run method of the DIAGNOSE object
Example Link: and Close and Open methods of the DIAGSPEC object clarify the default model families that are diagnosed

Short Update: The Interactive Modeling node shows the parent champion node

Example Link: it is listed in the Model Selection List table when the Ensemble node is the champion for the selected time series. However

Short Update: A new pipeline template has been added to The Exchange for Hierarchical Modeling
Long Update: his allows you to specify Hierarchical Modeling as the initial pipeline by default for a new project. It also enables you to specify Hierarchical Modeling when creating a new pipeline

Short Update: A new modeling node
Long Update: Hierarchical Modeling
Example Link: This node enables you to run separate pipelines for each level in the project hierarchy. For each level
Release: you can add multiple modeling nodes with your own customizations and interactive modeling. You can use the Save Data node to save output tables for each modeling node within the pipelines for each level. The Ensemble node can also be used within each pipeline to collect the best models for each time series

Short Update: Time Series Analysis (TSA) Package: You can now detect outliers in time series data by using the new objects TSAOUTLIER & TSAOUTOUTLIER
Long Update: TSAOUTLIER object detects outliers in the specified time series by using the Hampel-identifier-based outlier detection method. You can specify various options to control the outlier detection process. TSAOUTOUTLIER object collects the detected outliers from the TSAOUTLIER object

Short Update: New Custom Time Interval Processing macro
Long Update: The new SAS macro %VF_CustInt enables you to validate an interval data set. If the data set provides a valid custom interval
Document Link: the macro loads the custom interval onto a CAS server. Otherwise
Example Link: you can choose to print the output to provide details about the data quality issues. It is a useful tool for both generating valid custom intervals and loading them onto CAS servers

Short Update: Automatic Time Series Modeling (ATSM) Package: Change in the DIAGNOSE object default behavior
Long Update: The default behavior of the DIAGNOSE object has been changed to match the documented behavior of the SetARIMAXRefine() and SetUCMRefine() methods of the DIAGSPEC object. Absence of either of these methods in your program is now equivalent to calling the respective method with its default options

Short Update: Open Source Distributed Code Update
Long Update: change VF_STDEV to VF_STD
Document Link: . The VF_STDEV variable has been used for the open source code to provide the prediction standard errors. If you are using this variable for your open source program
Example Link: you must change this variable name to VF_STD

Short Update: Enhancement for Importing Forecasting projects with custom events
Long Update: Starting in 2024.01
Document Link: if there is a name conflict between the custom event in the SAS Forecast Studio project and one of the predefined events

Short Update: Add events to Interactive Modeling custom models that have not been defined for use in the project
Long Update: Starting with this release
Document Link: you can add events to these custom models that have not been defined for use in the project. These events are used without any restrictions
Example Link: whereas events that are allowed for project use are defined with specific restrictions.If you are creating an ARIMA

Short Update: The custom definition of discrete time intervals is now available for use with Proc TSMODEL and interval-related functions in Data Steps that run in CAS
Long Update: You can access this functionality by using the following two settings together: the INTERVALDS= CAS session option to associate the interval name with the custom interval definition table
Document Link: the new loadCustIntTable action in the new dateTimeCalc action set to load the custom interval definition into a CAS session

Short Update: New fit statistic: RMSSE is avaialble for model selection
Long Update: RMSSE is the mean square error of the forecast values
Document Link: which is computed by scaling the error on the basis of the in-sample MAE from the one-step-ahead naive (random walk) forecast method

Short Update: New fit statistic: IMASE is available for model selection
Long Update: IMASE is the mean absolute error (MAE) of the forecast values
Document Link: which is computed by scaling the error on the basis of the in-sample MAE from the one-step-ahead naive (random walk) forecast method

Short Update: Two new fit statistics
Long Update: IMASE (in-sample mean absolute scaled error) and RMSSE (root mean square scaled error).
Example Link: IMASE (in-sample mean absolute scaled error) and RMSSE (root mean square scaled error)

Short Update: The pipeline provides an Ensemble node that you can connect to multiple modeling nodes in the pipeline.
Long Update: The Ensemble node evaluates the forecasts from each of the connected modeling nodes and selects forecasts for each time series based on the fit statistics that you select. As a result
Document Link: the forecasts from the Ensemble node provide the most accurate results from the connected modeling nodes.

Short Update: Series Analysis Enhancements
Long Update: New stationarity tests are available to test zero-mean stationarity

Short Update: Series Analysis Enhancements
Long Update: New analyses are available from the Series Analysis tab in Interactive Modling.

Short Update: TSM Package documentation improvement
Long Update: The descriptions of the TSM.AddX()
Example Link: and UCMSPEC.AddInput() methods have been revised for clarity.

Short Update: Enhancements for Events
Long Update: In the list of custom events on the Data tab
Document Link: you can display a thumbnail of a plot for each event by hovering your mouse over the event.

Short Update: ATSM Package enhancment for outlier detection
Long Update: New capability has been added to enable you to detect outliers in time series data. You can use the following new objects: OUTLIER

Short Update: SAS Visual Forecasting provides predefined events for common holidays.
Long Update: SAS Visual Forecasting provides predefined events for common holidays. Starting with this release
Document Link: the predefined events are already included in each project. The system usage for these events is automatically set to Do not use.

Short Update: Creating Events for a SAS Visual Forecasting Project
Long Update: You can now create your own events for a project from the Data tab in Model Studio. The event types include the same types you can create in SAS Forecast Studio

Short Update: Enhancements to the Modeling Tab in Forecast Viewer
Long Update: Starting with 2023.08
Document Link: the modeling tab shows the model selection list and the statistics of fit when the node is run using the Update

Short Update: Enhancement to the Automatic Time Series Modeling (ATSM) Package
Long Update: The PERIOD option of the EVENTDEF and EVENTKEY methods in the EVENT object now supports two regime-shift values

Short Update: Enhanced support for Importing SAS Forecast Studio Projects
Long Update: When importing projects from SAS Forecast Studio
Document Link: you can specify different caslibs to store the source input data for the project. Prior to 2023.08
Example Link: the input data for the project was always imported to the default caslib.

Short Update: Documentation Enhancement for Time Series Model (TSM) Package
Long Update: The descriptions of the Variance and Noest arguments of the following methods of the UCMSPEC object have been improved to add clarity AddAutoreg()
column8: and AddSeason(). Similar improvements have been made to the documentation of the CoeffArray and Noest arguments of the UCMSPEC.AddDeplag() method.

Short Update: Documentation Enhancement for ERRORSTOP in Proc Tsmodel.
Long Update: Documentation has been added for the ERRORSTOP= option in the PROC TSMODEL statement. This option enables you to control whether the program stops running when an error occurs during execution of package functions or object methods.

Short Update: Distributed Open Source Code Node
Long Update: A new modeling node is available in the forecasting pipeline. The Distributed Open Source Code node enables model developers
column8: to provide their own open source code to perform time series forecasting for a project. This node supports open source code written in R or Python.

Short Update: Custom Time Interval Processing for use in Proc Tsmodel
Long Update: Time Series Processing Action Set and interval-related functions in Data Step/Proc CAS
Document Link: The custom definition of discrete time intervals is now available in SAS Viya. This feature enables you to create and use your own discrete time intervals to supplement the list of predefined discrete time intervals

Short Update: From the Modeling tab in Interactive Modeling
Long Update: you can open a plot and table for the unbiasedness test of the predicted values.
Document Link: Unbiasedness test — The plot produced by this analysis shows the predicted values against the actual values and includes the estimates
Release: and significance-level indicators of the t test (asterisks next to the standard error) for intercept and slope parameters of the fitted regression line.

Short Update: Two new plots in the Interactive Modeling node
Long Update: New plots have been added to Series Analysis and the Modeling tabs in Interactive Modeling. With this release
Document Link: you can view the spectral density plot for any selected time series on the Series Analysis tab. On the Modeling tab
Example Link: you can view the plot for the prediction error spectral density of a selected time series.

Short Update: OutRNNOpt and OutRNNStat have been added output collector object for the RNN training process
Long Update: Two new output collector objects have been added to enable you to collect information about the training process of an RNN forecasting model: OUTRNNOPT: collects the optimization history
Document Link: which includes training and validation errors for each epoch. OUTRNNSTAT: collects the training status and summary
Example Link: which includes the optimal epoch and error metrics at that epoch.

Short Update: GetTime() method as been added to Proc TsModel.
Long Update: The GetTime() method enables you to retrieve the current time (in seconds) relative to the start of the execution of PROC TSMODEL. You can use it to measure the performance of portions of your user-defined code.

Short Update: Local Value Lists
Long Update: On the Value Lists tab in a segmentation tree
Document Link: you can define local value lists for use within that segmentation tree only

Short Update: Segmentation Tree Enhancements
Long Update: You can export and import data grid reference variables and their associated data grid variable from a segmentation tree

Short Update: Segmentation Tree Enhancements
Long Update: You can copy and paste an entire branch path in a segmentation tree

Short Update: Customize Direction When Adding Missing Variables
Long Update: When you add a new object to a decision
Document Link: you can customize the direction (input or output) of variables in the Add Missing Variables window. The default input and output settings match the settings in the object
Example Link: but you can change them to match how the object is used in the decision

Short Update: New data grid functions are added that support the use of OR operations between conditions that select rows for processing
Long Update: COLUMNCOUNTMATCHBYFILTER

Short Update: View Function Documentation in the Expression Editor
Long Update: In the expression editor
Document Link: you can hover over a function name on the Functions tab to display a brief description of the function
Release: and a description of each of its arguments

Short Update: Insert New Nodes into Segmentation Tree Branches
Long Update: You can insert new nodes in front of any existing node in a segmentation tree

Short Update: Preview Value Lists
Long Update: When you associate a value list with a variable
Document Link: the Choose Value List Version window displays the values and labels that are defined in the selected version of the value list

Short Update: In the rule set editor
Long Update: you can use the Undo and Redo buttons
Document Link: You can undo any change that you make to a rule set in an editing session

Short Update: Use Value Lists
Long Update: A value list is the list of acceptable values for a variable. Entries in a value list can be discrete values or ranges of values. You use value lists to define variables and matrices in segmentation trees. When you add a variable or matrix to the segmentation tree
Document Link: SAS Intelligent Decisioning creates new branches in the tree.

Short Update: New Segmentation Tree Node added
Long Update: A segmentation tree is a hierarchical structure that consists of a root node
Example Link: and final leaf nodes called outcomes. Any branch can lead to additional branches or to an outcome. Outcomes define actions to be taken when all of the branch criteria leading to the outcome are satisfied.

Short Update: New Step: Neural Network
Long Update: The Neural Network step creates a multilayer perceptron neural network. You can create networks with up to 10 hidden layers

Short Update: New Step: Mixed Models
Long Update: The Mixed Models step fits a variety of mixed linear models to data and enables you to use these fitted models to make inferences about the data. A mixed linear model is a generalization of the standard linear model. The generalization is that the data is permitted to exhibit correlation and nonconstant variability. Therefore
Document Link: the mixed linear model provides the flexibility to model the means of your data (as in the standard linear model) and also the variances and covariances

Short Update: New Step: Proportional Hazards Regression
Long Update: The Proportional Hazards Regression step fits proportional hazards regression models to survival data. These models include the widely used semi-parametric Cox regression model and its extensions
Document Link: such as the shared frailty model and the Fine-Gray model. The step supports the analysis of data that might be left-censored

Short Update: New Step: Subsequence Anomaly Detection
Long Update: The Subsequence Anomaly Detection step is a motif-based technique that finds anomaly subsequences in a specified input sequence

Short Update: New Step: Generalized Linear Models
Long Update: The Generalized Linear Models step provides model fitting and model building for generalized linear models. It fits models for standard distributions such as Normal
Example Link: and Tweedie in the exponential family. This step also fits multinomial models for ordinal and nominal responses. The step provides forward

Short Update: New Step: Cross-Sectional Data Models
Long Update: The Cross-Sectional Data Models step applies econometric techniques to analyze cross-sectional data

Short Update: New Step: Univariate Time Series Analysis
Long Update: The Univariate Time Series Analysis step analyzes a single time series in which the values are equally spaced. This task provides analysis for these model types: ARIMA (autoregressive integrated moving average)
Release: and regression with autocorrelated and heteroscedastic errors

Short Update: New Step: Sample Data
Long Update: The Sample Data step performs simple or stratified random sampling or oversampling of the input data source

Short Update: New Step: Motif Discovery
Long Update: The Motif Discovery step provides methods to discover frequent patterns or repeated subsequences in time series data

Short Update: New Step: Similarity Analysis
Long Update: The Similarity Analysis step provides methods to measure the similarity between two time series or among sequences in temporal data

Short Update: New Step: Modeling and Forecasting
Long Update: The Modeling and Forecasting step creates forecasting models that use your time series data. This step requires data in a valid time series format

Short Update: New Step: N-Way ANOVA
Long Update: The N-way ANOVA step tests and provides graphs for effects of one or more factors on the means of a single

Short Update: New Step: Motif Scoring
Long Update: The Motif Scoring step tries to find subsequences that are most similar to the target sequence in a new time series

Short Update: New Step: Multivariate Time Series Analysis
Long Update: The Multivariate Time Series Analysis step analyzes a vector of time series that are equally spaced

Short Update: New Step: Nonparametric Survival Analysis
Long Update: The Nonparametric Survival Analysis step computes nonparametric estimates of the survival distribution function and compares survival functions of two or more groups

Short Update: New Step: Partial Least Squares Regression
Long Update: The Partial Least Squares Regression step performs partial least squares analysis. It also performs principal components regression and reduced rank regression. These techniques combine dimension reduction of the predictors and dependent variables with predictive modeling

Short Update: New Step: Severity Models
Long Update: The Severity Models step estimates parameters of any arbitrary continuous probability distribution that is used to model the magnitude (severity) of a continuous-valued event of interest

Short Update: New Step: Predictive Regression Models
Long Update: The step is predictive in that it selects the most influential effects based on observed data. This step enables you to logically partition your data into disjoint subsets for model training
Example Link: and testing. The Predictive Regression Models step focuses on the standard independently and identically distributed general linear model for univariate responses and offers great flexibility and insight into the model selection algorithm

Short Update: New Step: Variable Selection
Long Update: The Variable Selection step enables you to perform unsupervised and supervised variable selection. The task identifies a set of variables that explain the maximum amount of data variance that is contained in the target variable or the data source

Short Update: New Step: Logistic Regression Statistical Power
Long Update: The Logistic Regression Statistical Power step calculates power and sample size analyses for the likelihood ratio chi-square test of a single predictor in binary logistic regression. This calculation possibly occurs in the presence of one or more covariates that might be correlated with the tested predictor

Short Update: New Step: Market Basket Analysis
Long Update: The Market Basket Analysis step performs association rule mining on a transaction data set

Short Update: New Step: Discriminant Analysis
Long Update: For a set of observations with one or more quantitative variables and a classification variable
Document Link: the Discriminant Analysis step develops a discriminant criterion to classify each observation into a group. The derived discriminant criterion from this data set can be applied to a second data set during the same run

Short Update: New Step: Wilcoxon Test Statistical Power
Long Update: The Wilcoxon Statistical Power step calculates power and sample size analyses for the Wilcoxon-Mann-Whitney test for two independent groups

Short Update: New Step: Tests of Proportions Statistical Power
Long Update: Power and sample size analysis optimizes the resource usage and design of a study
Document Link: which improves the chances of conclusive results with maximum efficiency. The Tests of Proportions Statistical Power step calculates the power or sample size for tests of one proportion

Short Update: New Step: Quantile Regression
Long Update: The Quantile Regression step fits predictive models by using quantile regression with automated model selection

Short Update: New Step: Panel Data Models
Long Update: The Panel Data Models step enables you to run analyses for a variety of model types. You can analyze a class of linear econometric models that commonly arise when time series and cross-sectional data is combined. This type of pooled data on time series cross-sectional bases is often referred to as panel data. This step also handles cross-sectional data (data without the time ID values)

Short Update: New Step: Spatial Regression Models
Long Update: The Spatial Regression Models step analyzes a class of linear spatial econometric models for cross-sectional data whose observations are spatially referenced or georeferenced

Short Update: New Step: Partition Data
Long Update: The Partition Data step enables you to create up to four partitions that are created by randomly sampling the input data. Partitions can be used to develop a model. In this case
Document Link: you want to train the model on part of the data and reserve some of the data for testing. Using the Partition Data step
Example Link: you can save all the partitions to one output data set or save each partition in a separate table

Short Update: New Step: Logistic Regression
Long Update: The Logistic Regression step fits predictive models by using logistic regression of a binary response and automated model selection and validation

Short Update: New Step: ANOVA Statistical Power
Long Update: The ANOVA Statistical Power step calculates power and sample size analyses for one degree of freedom contrasts and the overall F test

Short Update: New Step: Gradient Boosting
Long Update: The Gradient Boosting step produces an ensemble of tree-based statistical models called decision trees for interval or nominal targets. It uses the gradient boosting approach

Short Update: New Step: Confidence Intervals Statistical Power
Long Update: The Confidence Intervals Statistical Power step calculates the power or sample size for these confidence intervals: one-sample means

Short Update: New Step: Survival Rank Tests Step
Long Update: The Survival Rank Tests step calculates power
Example Link: or number of events for two-sample survival rank tests

Short Update: New Step: t Tests Statistical Power Step
Long Update: The t Tests Statistical Power step calculates the power or sample size for t tests of means and mean ratios

Short Update: New Step: Cox Regression Statistical Power Step
Long Update: The Cox Regression Statistical Power step calculates the power or sample size for the score test. This test is for a single scalar predictor in Cox proportional hazards regression for survival data

Short Update: New Step: Custom Tests Statistical Power Step
Long Update: The Custom Tests Statistical Power step calculates power or sample size for test statistics from the chi-square

Short Update: New Step: Hierarchical Clustering
Long Update: The Hierarchical Clustering step enables you to perform hierarchical cluster analysis. The Hierarchical Clustering step can be used with either coordinate data or distance data

Short Update: New Step: K-Means Clustering
Long Update: The K-Means Clustering step enables you to cluster interval or ratio data using the k-means algorithm. This step is a good starting point for cluster analysis

Short Update: New Step: Aggregate Loss Models
Long Update: The Aggregate Loss Models step computes an estimate of the probability distribution model of the aggregate loss. This estimate is based on the knowledge of the distribution of loss severity and loss count

Short Update: New Step: Community Detection Step
Long Update: The Community Detection step partitions a graph into communities such that the nodes within the community subgraphs are more densely connected than the nodes from different communities

Short Update: New Step: Principal Component Analysis Step
Long Update: Principal component analysis is a multivariate technique for examining relationships among several quantitative variables. Use principal component analysis if you are interested in summarizing data and detecting linear relationships

Short Update: New Step: Forest Step
Long Update: The Forest step produces an ensemble of tree-based statistical models called decision trees for interval or nominal targets. It uses the Random Forest approach

Short Update: New Step: Multiple Regression Statistical Power Step
Long Update: Power and sample size analysis optimizes the resource usage and design of a study
Document Link: which improves the chances of conclusive results with maximum efficiency. The Multiple Regression Statistical Power step calculates the power or sample size for multiple regression

Short Update: New Step: Equivalence Tests Statistical Power Step
Long Update: The Equivalence Tests Statistical Power step performs power analysis and sample size determination for equivalence tests of one-sample mean

Short Update: New Step: Text Parsing and Topic Discovery Step
Long Update: The Text Parsing and Topic Discovery step is used to parse documents into a term-by-document matrix and extract topics from the term-by-document matrix

Short Update: New Step: Shortest Paths Step
Long Update: The Shortest Paths step calculates paths between sets of nodes in the input graph with the lowest total link weight

Short Update: New Step: Linear Assignment Step
Long Update: The Linear Assignment step assigns any objects from one group to objects in a second group at minimal costs

Short Update: New Step: Factorization Machine Step
Long Update: The Factorization Machine step combines the advantages of smart machine vision (SMV) with factorization models

Short Update: New Step: Connected Components Step
Long Update: The Connected Components step finds all the connected components in a graph. A connected component in a graph is a set of nodes that have a path between them

Short Update: New Step: Bayesian Network Step
Long Update: The Bayesian Network step trains a predictive model of a nominal target using different types of Bayesian network structures

Short Update: New Step: Support Vector Machine
Long Update: The Support Vector Machine step performs classification analysis for binary targets by using a support vector machine
Document Link: which is a supervised machine learning method

Short Update: New Step: Reach Network
Long Update: The Reach Network step calculates the reach (ego) network of a graph. In the context of social networks
Document Link: reach networks are often referred to as ego networks
Example Link: because they focus on the neighbors of one particular individual (or more than one)

Short Update: New Step: Cycle Detection
Long Update: The Cycle Detection step finds the elementary cycles of an input graph. An elementary cycle is a path in which the start node and the end node are the same
Document Link: and no node appears more than once in the sequence

Short Update: New Step: Automated Feature Engineering
Long Update: The Automated Feature Engineering step explores the variables in the input data and automatically performs feature engineering in a parallel

Short Update: New Step: Transitive Closure Step
Long Update: The Transitive Closure step calculates the transitive closure of a graph

Short Update: New Step: Decision Tree Step
Long Update: The Decision Tree step produces tree-based statistical models called decision trees for nominal and interval targets

Short Update: New Step: Summary and Level Statistics Step
Long Update: The Summary and Level Statistics step computes level and descriptive statistics for variables in a data source

Short Update: New Step: Summary Tables Step
Long Update: The Summary Tables step displays descriptive statistics in tabular format
Document Link: using some or all of the variables in a data set. You can create a variety of tables
Example Link: ranging from simple to highly customized

Short Update: New Step: Segmentation Step
Long Update: The Segmentation step segments text data using k-means clustering

Short Update: New Step: Mosaic Plot Step
Long Update: Mosaic plots display tiles that correspond to the crosstabulation table cells. The areas of the tiles are proportional to the frequencies of the table cells. The column variable is displayed on the X axis
Document Link: and the tile widths are proportional to the relative frequencies of the column variable levels

Short Update: New Step: Minimum Spanning Tree Step
Long Update: A spanning tree of a connected undirected graph is a subgraph. This subgraph is a tree that connects all the nodes. The Minimum Spanning Tree (MST) step finds the spanning tree
Example Link: that has the minimum link cost

Short Update: New Step: Minimum Cost Network Flow Step
Long Update: The Minimum Cost Network Flow (MCF) step is a fundamental problem in network analysis that involves sending flow over a network at minimal cost

Short Update: New Step: Text Scoring Step
Long Update: The Text Scoring step scores a data table using tables that are generated by another Text Analytics step

Short Update: New step: Traveling Salesman Problem
Long Update: The traveling salesman problem (TSP) finds a minimum-cost tour in a graph. A tour of a graph is a sequence of nodes where the start node and end node are the same
Document Link: and every node in the graph is visited exactly once. In solving the TSP
Example Link: the goal is to find a tour that minimizes the costs of the links

Short Update: New step: Nonparametric One-Way ANOVA
Long Update: The Nonparametric One-Way ANOVA step consists of nonparametric tests for location and scale differences across a one-way classification. The step also provides a standard analysis of variance on the raw data and statistics based on the empirical distribution function

Short Update: New step: Minimum Cut
Long Update: The Minimum Cut step finds a minimum cut of an undirected graph that has the smallest link metric. A cut is a partition of the nodes of a graph into two disjoint subsets

Short Update: New step: Maximal Cliques
Long Update: The Maximal Cliques step finds the maximal cliques of a graph. A clique is an induced subgraph such that every node in that subgraph is connected to every other node. A maximal clique is a clique that is not a subset of the nodes of any larger clique

Short Update: New step: Biconnected Components
Long Update: A biconnected component of an undirected graph is a connected subgraph that cannot be broken into disconnected pieces by deleting any single node (and its incident links). The Biconnected Components step finds all biconnected components of such a graph

Short Update: New step: Analysis of Covariance
Long Update: The Analysis of Covariance step fits a linear model that combines the continuous and categorical predictors of a continuous dependent variable. This step also produces graphical output to interpret the results

Short Update: New step: Centrality Metrics
Long Update: The Centrality Metrics step calculates several types of centrality metrics that indicate the relative importance of a node or link within a graph

Short Update: New step: Estimate Within-Cluster Covariances
Long Update: The Estimate Within-Cluster Covariances step uses the Art
Example Link: and Kettenring method to estimate within-cluster covariances. This approach might result in more spherical clusters when the resulting canonical variables are clustered

Short Update: New step: Linear Regression
Long Update: Using the Linear Regression step
Document Link: you can perform linear regression analysis on multiple dependent and independent variables

Short Update: New Step: Hidden Markov Models in Econometrics
Long Update: The Hidden Markov Models step analyzes the time series or panel data by using a statistical Markov model to infer hidden states through a Markov process

Short Update: New Step: One-Way ANOVA in Statistics
Long Update: The One-Way ANOVA step tests and provides graphs for differences among the means of a single categorical variable on a single continuous dependent variable

Short Update: New Step: Text Summarization in Text Analytics
Long Update: The Text Summarization step generates textual summaries of text data

Short Update: New Step: Support Vector Data Description in Machine Learning
Long Update: The Support Vector Data Description step is a one-class classification machine learning technique

Short Update: New Step: Semi-supervised Learning in Machine Learning
Long Update: The Semi-supervised Learning step iteratively propagates the labels from the labeled data to the unlabeled data by computing the similarity measure between pairs of data

Short Update: New Step: Network Summary in Optimization and Network Analysis
Long Update: The Network Summary step calculates various summary statistics for a graph and its nodes

Short Update: New Step: Capability Analysis in Statistical Process Control
Long Update: The Capability Analysis step compares the distribution of a process to its specification limits

Short Update: New Step: Multidimensional Preference Analysis
Long Update: The Multidimensional Preference Analysis step performs a principal components analysis of rank-ordered data. The principal result is a plot of the scores. These scores are the objects that are being rated. In the plot
Document Link: the scores are represented as points
Example Link: and the structure (raters) are represented as vectors. The Multidimensional Preference Analysis step is available in SAS Studio Analyst and SAS Studio Engineer

Short Update: New Step: Factor Analysis
Long Update: The Factor Analysis step performs a factor analysis with a variety of available methods and rotations. The Factor Analysis step is available in SAS Studio Analyst and SAS Studio Engineer

Short Update: New Step: Correspondence Analysis
Long Update: The Correspondence Analysis step performs simple or multiple correspondence analysis of qualitative data. You can specify either raw data or table data for the input data source. The Correspondence Analysis step is available in SAS Studio Analyst and SAS Studio Engineer

Short Update: New Step: Core Decomposition
Long Update: The Core Decomposition step decomposes a graph into cohesive subgroups. The Core Decomposition step is available in SAS Studio Analyst and SAS Studio Engineer

Short Update: New Step: Compute Similarities and Distances
Long Update: The Compute Similarities and Distances step computes various measures of distance
Example Link: or similarity between observations in an input table. This information can be used in hierarchical cluster analysis and in multidimensional scaling. The Compute Similarities and Distances step is available in SAS Studio Analyst and SAS Studio Engineer

Short Update: New Step: Cluster Variables
Long Update: The Cluster Variables step finds clusters of variables to use in additional clustering or to select non-redundant variables in further clustering. The Cluster Variables step is available in SAS Studio Analyst and SAS Studio Engineer

Short Update: New Step: Causal Models
Long Update: The Causal Models step uses the two-stage least squares method and the Heckman's two-step selection method. The Causal Models step is available in SAS Studio Analyst and SAS Studio Engineer

Short Update: New Step: Canonical Correlation
Long Update: The Canonical Correlation step performs canonical correlation
Example Link: and canonical redundancy analysis. The Canonical Correlation step is available in SAS Studio Analyst and SAS Studio Engineer

Short Update: New Step: Fast k-Nearest Neighbors
Long Update: The Fast k-Nearest Neighbors step searches for the k-nearest neighbors (KNN) of the specified data. The Fast k-Nearest Neighbors step is available in SAS Studio Analyst and SAS Studio Engineer

Short Update: New Step: The t Tests step is available in SAS Studio Analyst or SAS Studio Engineer
Long Update: The t Tests step enables you to perform a one-sample test
Example Link: or a two-sample test. The t Tests step is available in SAS Studio Analyst or SAS Studio Engineer

Short Update: New Step: The Same Birthday Probability step is available in SAS Studio Analyst and SAS Studio Engineer
Long Update: The Same Birthday Probability step computes the probability that two or more people in a room have the same birthday. The Same Birthday Probability step is available in SAS Studio Analyst and SAS Studio Engineer

Short Update: New Step: The Poker Hand Probability step is available in SAS Studio Analyst and SAS Studio Engineer
Long Update: The Poker Hand Probability step calculates the frequency and probability of poker hands. The Poker Hand Probability step is available in SAS Studio Analyst and SAS Studio Engineer

Short Update: New Step: The Pareto Analysis step is available in SAS Studio Analyst and SAS Studio Engineer
Long Update: Pareto charts display the frequencies of quality-related problems in a process. The frequencies are represented by bars that are ordered in decreasing magnitude. Thus
Document Link: you can use a Pareto chart to decide which subset of problems to solve first or which problem areas deserve the most attention. The Pareto Analysis step is available in SAS Studio Analyst and SAS Studio Engineer

Short Update: New Step: The Moving Window Principal Component Analysis step is available in SAS Studio Analyst or SAS Studio Engineer
Long Update: The Moving Window Principal Component Analysis step can be used to assess how principal components change over time. The Moving Window Principal Component Analysis step is available in SAS Studio Analyst or SAS Studio Engineer

Short Update: New Step: The Control Charts step is available only if your site licenses SAS Studio Analyst or SAS Studio Engineer
Long Update: The Control Charts step creates Shewhart control charts for deciding whether a process is in a state of statistical control. The Control Charts step is available only if your site licenses SAS Studio Analyst or SAS Studio Engineer

Short Update: New Step: The Coin Toss Simulation step is available in SAS Studio Analyst and SAS Studio Engineer
Long Update: The Coin Toss Simulation task simulates the tossing of a specified number of coins. The results show the frequency and percentage of occurrences that the coin displays heads given a specified number of tosses. The Coin Toss Simulation step is available in SAS Studio Analyst and SAS Studio Engineer

Short Update: New Step: The Analysis of Means step is available in SAS Studio Analyst or SAS Studio Engineer
Long Update: Analysis of means is a method for simultaneously comparing treatment means with their overall mean. The Analysis of Means step is available in SAS Studio Analyst or SAS Studio Engineer

Short Update: Grow a New Decision Tree from Decision Tree Node
Long Update: You can now grow a new decision tree from a node on an existing decision tree. Right-click a node and select Grow tree. You can place the new tree on the same page or on a new page of the repor

Short Update: Improvements to Autotuning
Long Update: The champion model is now displayed at the top of the list in the Autotuning Results table. When you are viewing results
Document Link: you can now apply any row's hyperparameters to the model. The existing autotune results are still available. You can now sort by column in the Autotuning Results table.

Short Update: Enhancement to Proc: TREESPLIT
Long Update: The new MITIGATEBIAS statement enables you to train a decision tree model while reducing the bias metric across the categorical groups of a variable that you specify in the SENSITIVEVAR= option. When you choose to reduce the bias metric across the categorical groups of this variable
Document Link: PROC TREESPLIT trains a series of decision trees iteratively and selects for the trained model the decision tree that has the least bias

Short Update: Summary Variables in Decision Trees objects
Long Update: You can now add summary variables to decision tree models with the Node details variable

Short Update: New Action Set: superLearner
Long Update: A super learner is a predictive model that combines predictions from other models. The new superLearner action set provides the slTrain and slScore actions
Document Link: which enable you to train and score a super learner model for continuous or binary response variables and to compute predictive margins

Short Update: New Proc: SUPERLEARNER
Long Update: A super learner is a predictive model that combines predictions from other models. You can use the new SUPERLEARNER procedure to train and score a super learner model for continuous or binary response variables and to compute predictive margins

Short Update: Enhancement to regression.logistic Action:now makes LS-means analyses available when you restore an item store
Long Update: The logistic action now make LS-means analyses available when you restore an item store

Short Update: Enhancement to Proc: LOGSELECT
Long Update: now makes LS-means analyses available when you use the RESTORE option
Example Link: now makes LS-means analyses available when you use the RESTORE option

Short Update: Enhancement to Proc: GENSELECT
Long Update: now makes LS-means analyses available when you use the RESTORE option
Example Link: now makes LS-means analyses available when you use the RESTORE option

Short Update: Enhancement to regression.genmod Action: now makes LS-means analyses available when you restore an item store
Long Update: The genmod action now make LS-means analyses available when you restore an item store

Short Update: General Enhancement: There is a new icon for derived categories
Long Update: There is a new icon for derived categories

Short Update: General Enhancement: There is a new icon for derived measures
Long Update: There is a new icon for derived measures

Short Update: Enhancement to Proc: ASSESS
Long Update: The new NOMISSINGTARGET option excludes observations that have missing values of a nominal target from assessment analysis

Short Update: General Enhancement: Deprecated Option for Decision Trees Is Removed
Long Update: The deprecated Rapid growth option is now removed from any existing reports when you promote them to this release

Short Update: New Proc: CATTRANSFORM
Long Update: The new CATTRANSFORM procedure transforms categorical variables by using several supervised and unsupervised binning algorithms
Document Link: which enable you to reduce variable cardinality. These algorithms include grouping rare levels
column8: and weight-of-evidence binning. In addition to providing binning algorithms
column9: the procedure supports one-hot encoding for categorical variables

Short Update: Enhancement to Proc GAMSELECT: create variables on the fly
Long Update: The GAMSELECT procedure now enables you to use programming statements to create variables on the fly for model effects and splines

Short Update: Removal of the Deprecated Bin Response Variable Option for Decision Trees
Long Update: The deprecated Bin response variable option is now removed from any existing reports when you promote them to this release. Use a custom category to bin the response variable and create the effects of this property

Short Update: Enhancement to Proc PHSELECT: support for MULTIPASS option added
Long Update: The procedure now supports the MULTIPASS= option
Document Link: which enables you to specify whether data are levelized during model fitting. When MULTIPASS=FALSE
Release: model fitting runs faster but uses more memory than when MULTIPASS=TRUE

Short Update: Enhancement to the bartProbit action: fit probit Bayesian additive regression trees (BART) models of binary response variables
Long Update: The new bartProbit action fits probit Bayesian additive regression trees (BART) models of binary response variables. You can save models that are fitted by this action as analytic stores
Document Link: which you can use in subsequent analyses. The bartProbit and bartGauss actions support predictive margin computations when you train a model

Short Update: Enhancement to the BART proc: supports probit models for binary response variables
Long Update: The procedure now supports probit models for binary response variables
Document Link: the computation of predictive margins by using the MARGINS statement
Example Link: and a RESTORE= option that enables you to read a previously fitted model. You can use the DIST= option in the MODEL statement to specify the distribution of the response variable. You can use a previously fitted model to either score new data by using the OUTPUT statement or compute predictive margins by using the MARGIN statement

Short Update: New Support for Exporting an Analytic Store Table
Long Update: You can now choose to export an analytic store table for the following models: decision tree

Short Update: New Proc: EFA
Long Update: The new EFA procedure implements methods and algorithms for exploratory factor analysis. You can request multiple criteria to determine the number of factors to extract. The procedure also supports a variety of methods for specifying prior communalities

Short Update: New Action for factorAnalysis Action Set: faExtract
Long Update: The new faExtract action implements methods that enable you to extract common factors and rotate the corresponding factor pattern. This action supports multiple algorithms for factor extraction
Document Link: including principal factor extraction (iterated or noniterated)
Release: and the least squares method. It also supports multiple algorithms for factor rotation
column8: including promax and the generalized Crawford-Ferguson family of rotations

Short Update: Enhancments to the regression.logistic Action: elastic net selection method
Long Update: The elastic net selection method in the logistic action now supports generalized logit models for nominal response data

Short Update: Enhancments to the regression.genmod Action: linear constraints on model parameters
Long Update: The genmod action now supports linear constraints on model parameters

Short Update: Enhancement to the Proc LOGSELECT: support for generalized logit
Long Update: The elastic net selection method now supports generalized logit models for nominal response data

Short Update: Enhancement to the Proc GENSELECT: RESTRICT now supports linear constraints
Long Update: RESTRICT statement in this procedure now supports the specification of linear constraints on model parameters

Short Update: regression.genmod & regression.logistic action enhancement: new noxpx parameter
Long Update: The genmod and logistic actions suppress all matrix computations when you specify the new noxpx parameter. Suppression of the matrix computations reduces the amount of memory that is required. This is useful in predictive analytics
Document Link: where you might be fitting models that have a large number of variables

Short Update: pca.eig action enhancement: new gpu parameter
Long Update: The new gpu parameter in the eig action enables you to use to perform model computation on GPU-equipped machines (one GPU is used on each machine)

Short Update: Proc PCA enhancement: new GPU option for eig method
Long Update: The eigenvalue decomposition (EIG) method in PROC PCA now supports the GPU option
Document Link: which enables you to use GPUs to perform model computation on GPU-equipped machines (one GPU is used on each machine)

Short Update: Proc GENSELECT & Proc LOGSELECT enhancement: new noxpx option
Long Update: These procedures suppress all matrix computations when you specify the new NOXPX option. Suppression of the matrix computations reduces the amount of memory that is required. This is useful in predictive analytics
Document Link: where you might be fitting models that have a large number of variables

Short Update: Proc Regselect: The procedure now supports relaxed LASSO selection
Long Update: The procedure now performs relaxed LASSO selection when you specify the METHOD=LASSO(RELAXED) option in the SELECTION statement. The relaxed LASSO estimator is a linear combination of the original LASSO solution and least squares estimates. The relaxed LASSO has been shown to outperform the original LASSO in many cases

Short Update: Proc Logselect: The elastic net selection method now supports cumulative link models for ordinal response data
Long Update: The elastic net selection method now supports cumulative link models for ordinal response data

Short Update: Enhancement to model objects: Titles for models that are in reports are now automatically generated by default
Long Update: Titles for models that are in reports are now automatically generated by default. You can change this setting under the Report Defaults heading in the Settings window.

Short Update: The glm action now supports relaxed LASSO selection
Long Update: The glm action now supports relaxed LASSO selection when you specify 'LASSO' in the method subparameter and True in the relaxed subparameter of the selection parameter. The elastic net selection of the logistic action now supports cumulative link models for ordinal response data

Short Update: New statement in Proc Tressplit: CROSSVALIDATION
Long Update: The TREESPLIT procedure now supports the CROSSVALIDATION statement. This statement performs k-fold cross validation to assess the accuracy of a model

Short Update: The logistic regression model now includes the Odds Ratio plot
Long Update: The logistic regression model now includes the Odds Ratio plot. The Odds Ratio plot displays the odds ratio estimates for each variable in the model

Short Update: The logistic action now supports the elastic net method for model selection.
Long Update: The logistic action now supports the elastic net method for model selection. The elastic net method penalizes -2 log likelihood by adding both LASSO penalty and ridge penalty to achieve model selection and parameter estimation simultaneously. This method is useful when you have wide data (that is
Document Link: when the number of parameters could be much larger than the number of observations) or highly correlated variables.

Short Update: The LOGSELECT procedure now supports the elastic net model selection method when you specify the METHOD=ELASTICNET option.
Long Update: The elastic net method penalizes -2 log likelihood by adding both LASSO penalty and ridge penalty to achieve model selection and parameter estimation simultaneously. This method is useful when you have wide data (that is
Document Link: when the number of parameters could be much larger than the number of observations) or highly correlated variables.

Short Update: Confidence Level Option for GAM
Long Update: GLM
Example Link: You can now change the confidence level for generalized additive
column10: and nonparametric logistic regression models. The Confidence level option is available under the General heading in the Options pane.

Short Update: Abbreviated Large Numbers
Long Update: Large measure values are now abbreviated in models by default. For example
column8: 000 is displayed as 1.1B. You can change the Abbreviate numeric values option for a model under the Model Display heading in the Options pane.

Short Update: The logistic and genmod actions
Long Update: regression action set
Document Link: now support the new lsmeans parameter
Example Link: The logistic and genmod actions now support the new lsmeans parameter
Release: which enables you to compute least squares means of classification effects.

Short Update: The CAEFFECT procedure now supports the BY statement
Long Update: The CAEFFECT procedure now supports the BY statement
Document Link: which enables you to obtain separate analyses of observations in groups that are defined by the values of the BY variables.

Short Update: Support Vector Machine Enhancements
Long Update: You can now select additional kernel types for the support vector machine: sigmoid and radial basis function.

Short Update: New Proc CAEFFECT added
Long Update: The new CAEFFECT procedure implements model-agnostic estimation methods that enable you to adjust for confounding variables when you study the causal effect of a treatment variable on an outcome.

Short Update: New Option in Proc REGSELECT - PLOTS=RIDGE
Long Update: The PROC REGSELECT statement of the REGSELECT procedure now supports the PLOTS=RIDGE option
Document Link: which creates graphical panels of variance inflation factor (VIF) values and standardized ridge estimates by ridge values for each coefficient.

Short Update: New Option in Proc LOGSELECT and Proc GENSELECT - LSMEANS
Long Update: The new LSMEANS statement enables you to compute least squares means of classification effects.

Short Update: The new store parameter in the eig
Long Update: itergs
Example Link: and randompca actions (pca action set) saves the context and results of the statistical analysis to a binary compressed file
Release: The new store parameter in the eig
column10: and randompca actions saves the context and results of the statistical analysis to a binary compressed file. You can then retrieve the model information from the saved file to score a new data set by using the ASTORE procedure or the score action in the aStore action set.

Short Update: The new STORE statement (proc pca) saves the context and results of a statistical analysis to a binary compressed file
Long Update: The new STORE statement saves the context and results of a statistical analysis to a binary compressed file. You can then retrieve the model information from the file to score a new data set by using the ASTORE procedure or the score action in the aStore action set.

Short Update: The mixed action now supports the new at parameter
Long Update: The mixed action now supports the new at parameter
Document Link: which enables you to modify the covariate values that are used to compute LS-means.

Short Update: The LMIXED procedure now supports the AT= option in the LSMEANS statement
Long Update: The LMIXED procedure now supports the AT= option in the LSMEANS statement. This option enables you to modify the covariate values that are used to compute LS-means.

Short Update: Improvements to Autotuning
Long Update: now highlights champion model
Document Link: Autotuning now highlights the champion model in the results table. You can now view the history of calculations based on the objective metric in the results table.

Short Update: Enhancements to the Regression (regression) Action Set
Long Update: specifically to the genmod & logistic actions.
Document Link: The logistic and genmod actions now support a restore parameter that enables you to read a previously stored model
Example Link: replay the tables that were produced when the model was fit
Release: and apply the stored model to a new input data table in order to produce other postfit analyses. The storeText parameter enables you to add notes to an item store that are then replayed when you restore a model. The fitData parameter declares the input data table to be the original data table used to fit the stored model when the new restore parameter is also specified.

Short Update: Enhancements to the GENSELECT & LOGSELECT procs.
Long Update: The new RESTORE= option enables you to read a previously stored model
Document Link: replay the tables that were produced when the model was fit
Example Link: and apply the stored model to a new data table in order to produce other postfit analyses. The STORE statement has a new TEXT= option that enables you to add notes to an item store that are then replayed when you restore a model. The FITDATA
column8: and TYPE3 options are now available as PROC statement options to support the new RESTORE= option.

Short Update: In the datagrid package
Long Update: new methods are added that support the use of OR operations between conditions that select rows for processing

Short Update: Support for LightGBM Models
Long Update: SAS Container Runtime now supports the execution of LightGBM analytic store (ASTORE) files

Short Update: In the datagrid package
Long Update: new methods are added that support the use of OR operations between conditions that select rows for processing

Short Update: Support for LightGBM Models
Long Update: SAS Micro Analytic Service now supports the execution of LightGBM analytic store (ASTORE) files

Short Update: Starting in SAS Viya 2025.02
Long Update: major enhancements to the SAS Compute Server simplify SAS programming by enabling advanced analytics procedures to run directly on the Compute Server
Example Link: major enhancements to the SAS Compute Server simplify SAS programming by enabling advanced analytics procedures to run directly on the Compute Server—eliminating the need for a CAS server in many cases. These updates introduce in-process execution

Long Update: The Gateway action set enables the user to run multiple sessions of supported open source engines for parallel processing and high efficiency of data transfer between SAS and open source. Users can use Python and R to interact with large SAS CAS tables that are securely stored in SAS.

Short Update: Enhanced Action Set: dagdisocvery action in the causal disocvery action set
Long Update: In the dagdiscovery action
Document Link: you can now perform computations for directed acyclic graph (DAG) structure learning by using graphics processing unit (GPU) hardware. GPUs can offer significantly faster performance than CPUs

Short Update: Enhanced Proc: CAUSALDISCOVERY
Long Update: You can now perform computations for directed acyclic graph (DAG) structure learning by using graphics processing unit (GPU) hardware. GPUs can offer significantly faster performance than CPUs

Short Update: In the dagdiscovery action
Long Update: the minimizing conditional variance (MCV) algorithm is added for directed acyclic graph (DAG) structure learning
Example Link: the minimizing conditional variance (MCV) algorithm is added for directed acyclic graph (DAG) structure learning. The MCV algorithm is very accurate and highly scalable
Release: requiring only a few seconds to learn a DAG that has 1

Short Update: Enhancement to Proc: CAUSALDISCOVERY The minimizing conditional variance (MCV) algorithm is added for directed acyclic graph (DAG) structure learning
Long Update: The minimizing conditional variance (MCV) algorithm is added for directed acyclic graph (DAG) structure learning. The MCV algorithm is very accurate and highly scalable
Document Link: requiring only a few seconds to learn a DAG that has 1

Short Update: Enhancement to the Proc DYNAMICLINEAR: OUTCOVARIANCE= option added
Long Update: The OUTCOVARIANCE= option is added to enable you to write the covariances of samples of in-sample and out-of-sample forecasting observations to an output table

Short Update: Enhancement to the severity Action Set: restrictions parameter added
Long Update: In the severity action
Document Link: the restrictions parameter is added to enable you to specify restrictions on scale model regression parameters during the model-fitting process

Short Update: Enhancement to the Proc SEVSELECT: restrict statement added
Long Update: The RESTRICT statement is added to enable you to specify restrictions on scale model regression parameters during the model-fitting process

Short Update: New Proc: CAUSALDISCOVERY
Long Update: The new CAUSALDISCOVERY procedure performs directed acyclic graph (DAG) structure learning by using the topological order permutation algorithm
Document Link: which is fast and accurate even with hundreds of variables. You can use a DAG to get a visual representation of causal relationships among a set of variables in many fields
column8: and medicine. The procedure also enables you to first simulate a DAG and then generate data from the simulated DAG
column9: as well as to evaluate the accuracy of an estimated DAG.

Short Update: New Action Set: causalDiscovery
Long Update: The new causalDiscovery action set includes three actions. The dagdiscovery action performs directed acyclic graph (DAG) structure learning by using the topological order permutation algorithm
Document Link: which is fast and accurate even with hundreds of variables. DAGs are used as a visual representation of the causal relationships among a set of variables in many fields
column8: and medicine. The dagsimulate action simulates a DAG and generates data from the simulated DAG
column9: and the dageval action evaluates the accuracy of an estimated DAG

Short Update: Proc CNTSELECT new suboption added: WARUMUP
Long Update: When set to True
Document Link: includes the tuning and burn-in iterations in the posterior sample table. Default is False

Short Update: Proc CNTSELECT new suboption added: NUTS
Long Update: To support the high-performance No-U-Turn Sampler for Bayesian inference
Document Link: the NUTS value is added to the sampler parameter

Short Update: countregFitModel action new parameter value added: NUTS for sampler
Long Update: To support the high-performance No-U-Turn Sampler for Bayesian inference
Document Link: the NUTS value is added to the sampler parameter

Short Update: countregFitModel action new parameter added: warmup
Long Update: When set to True
Document Link: includes the tuning and burn-in iterations in the posterior sample table. Default is False

Short Update: Proc HMM The MULTISTART option is now supported in distributed mode
Long Update: The MULTISTART option is now supported in distributed mode. In the distributed multistart algorithm
Document Link: the local optimizations that start from various initial points run concurrently.

Short Update: Hidden Markov Model Action Set now supports distributed mode for multistart
Long Update: The multistart algorithm is now supported in distributed mode with the new msMaxStarts
column8: and feSessNodes parameters. In the distributed multistart algorithm
column9: the local optimizations that start from various initial points run concurrently.

Short Update: CAS Action: ucmFit for UCM Action Set for nobserved components modeling of time series data.
Long Update: The ucmFit action in the new Unobserved Components Modeling (UCM) action set provides the full functionality of PROC UCM
Document Link: which is a SAS/ETS procedure that is used for unobserved components modeling of time series data.

Short Update: CAS enabled Proc: The UCM procedure in SAS Econometrics provides the full functionality of PROC UCM
Long Update: which is a SAS/ETS procedure that is used for unobserved components modeling of time series data.
Document Link: PROC UCM enables you to efficiently handle large numbers of BY groups by exploiting all the available cores and concurrent threads to process them in parallel.

Short Update: Proc X13: Additional statistics from “Table D8.A: F-Tests for Seasonality” are now available in the OUTSTAT= data set.
Long Update: Additional statistics from “Table D8.A: F-Tests for Seasonality” are now available in the OUTSTAT= data set. The OUTSTAT=
column8: and OUTPUT OUT= options are often used together to facilitate the processing of large numbers of series or BY groups in this procedure.

Short Update: SASEUSCB Interface Engine added support for additional US Census Bureau data
Long Update: This new interface to the US Census Bureau data supports the Advanced Report on Durable Goods
Release: and Orders (ADVM3) data set. Support for additional data sets will be provided in future versions of this software.

Short Update: SASEBLS interface to Local Area Unemployment Statistics (LAUS) data.

Document Link: this interface to US Bureau of Labor Statistics data now supports the Local Area Unemployment Statistics (LAUS) data.

Document Link: interface to US Bureau of Labor Statistics data
Example Link: now supports the Work Stoppages program (WSP) data.

Short Update: Proc HMM: The expectation-maximization (EM) algorithm is now supported in parallel mode on multiple threads and nodes.
Long Update: In Proc HMM in the optimize statement now supports for the suboption EM of the Algorithm option parallel mode to reduce run time and improve performance.

Short Update: FiniteHMM macro is a wrapper for finite HMM with PROC HMM
Long Update: The %FiniteHMM macro is a wrapper for finite HMM with PROC HMM. It treats the response variable as a categorical variable
Document Link: and it automatically preprocesses the data and postprocesses the results.

Short Update: SASEBLS Interface Engine now also supports Employment Projections and Occupational Requirements Survey
Long Update: This interface to US Bureau of Labor Statistics data now supports the Employment Projections (EP) program data and Occupational Requirements Survey (ORS) data.

Short Update: R SASCTL: Added scr_batch argument to format_data_json
Long Update: allowing to have all data in a single json payload for Viya 2024.7 SCR batch scoring feature
Example Link: allowing to have all data in a single json payload for Viya 2024.7 SCR batch scoring feature

Short Update: Enhancement to Proc: CAUSALTRT
Long Update: The new IPW(ATT)= option in the OUTPUT statement outputs the predicted inverse probability of treatment weights for the average treatment effect for the treated (ATT)
Document Link: The new IPW(ATT)= option in the OUTPUT statement outputs the predicted inverse probability of treatment weights for the average treatment effect for the treated (ATT)

Short Update: Enhancement to the MI proc: The new FLUX option generates an output table that contains new missing data statistics
Long Update: The new FLUX option generates an output table that contains new missing data statistics such as influx
Example Link: and the percentages of nonmissing observations for both categorical and numerical variables. The option also generates a scatter plot of influx and outflux statistics when ODS Graphics is turned on

Short Update: Proc LOGISTIC enhancements: A special odds ratio plot is now produced for continuous variables
Long Update: A special odds ratio plot is now produced for continuous variables that are used to construct spline effects or effects that are of second or higher degree

Short Update: Proc Logistic: The ID statement variables are now included in the OUTROC= data set

Long Update: The BGLIMM procedure now supports the DISTRIBUTION=BETA option in the MODEL statement. This option specifies the beta distribution for the response variable in the model.

Short Update: Senspec(cltype) option has been added to the table statements in Proc SurveyFreq
Long Update: The new SENSPEC(CLTYPE) option in the TABLES statement provides additional design-based confidence limit types for the sensitivity and specificity statistics. The new confidence limit types include logit and the following modified confidence limits: Agresti-Coull

Short Update: Margins statement has been added to the GEE Proc

Short Update: COMMONRISKDIFF has been added as an option for the Proc Freq tables statement.
Long Update: The new COMMONRISKDIFF(CL=MN) option in the TABLES statement provides Miettinen-Nurminen confidence limits for the common risk difference
Document Link: which is the overall difference in binomial proportions for stratified 2x2 tables.
